resources:
ComputerArchitecture Multithreading Computer Architecture Static Scheduling The Compiler can attempt to schedule instructions. Dynamic scheduling The Hardware rearranges the instruction execution to reduce the stalls. As soon as possible (ASAP) Executes instructions as soon as possible. As late as possible(ALAP) Executes instructions as late as possible.
Change threads in case of longer delays. Small delay can be tolerated when switching threads. Critical threads can be prioritized. Short stalls must be tolerated.
Change threads with each instruction. Any processor availability can be used. Higher latency of individual threads.
Multiple threads can be executed simultaneously on one CPU core. Instructions from different, independent threads can be executed simultaneously. Higher latency of individual threads, higher implementation effort
Advantages Disadvantages Simultaneous Multithreading Fine-grained Multithreading Coarse-grained Multithreading Hardware Layer Software Layer Speedup
A sequential program can be divided into 5 parts A to E, which must be executed in this order due to their dependencies. The table lists the amount of run-time each part contributes to the run-time of the program. Parts A, C and E cannot be parallelized. Part B can be transformed in max. 16 sub-parts that can be executed in parallel. For the parallel execution of part D, no restrictions exist.
Part Multiprocessor Systems NUMA Non-Uniform-Memory-Access "Memory access time depends on the memory location relative to the processor. Memory may be local, one hop away, or two hops away. " Graphics Processing Units OpenCL POSIX Threads Includes #include <pthread.h>
Thread Create pthread_create(thread, attr, start_routine, arg) Thread Exit pthread_exit(status) Thread Join pthread_join(thread, status) Thread Cancel pthread_cancel(thread) Thread Mutex Init pthread_mutex_init(mutex, attr) Thread Mutex Destroy pthread_mutex_destroy(mutex) Thread Mutex Lock pthread_mutex_lock(mutex) Thread Mutex Unlock pthread_mutex_unlock(mutex) Thread Condition Init pthread_cond_init(cond, attr) Thread Condition Wait pthread_cond_wait(cond, mutex) Thread Condition Signal pthread_cond_signal(cond)
thread attr start_routine arg Creates a new thread and makes it executable. An opaque, unique identifier for the new thread returned by the subroutine. An opaque attribute object that may be used to set thread attributes. You can specify a thread attributes object, or NULL for the default values. The C routine that the thread will execute once it is created. A single argument that may be passed to start_routine. It must be passed by reference as (void *).NULL may be used if no argument is to be passed. Caching Average Runtimes Block Placement Block Identification Block Replacement Write Strategy Where can a memory block be stored in the cache? Navigate to How is a memory block found? Which block should be replaced in the event of a failed access (cache miss)? What happens when data is written to the cache? Each block can be placed at exactly one location in the cache. Direct Mapping Set Associative Mapping Each block can be placed at a restricted set of locations in the cache. Associative Mapping Each block can be placed at any location in the cache. Tag The tag contains the most significant bits of the address, which are checked against all rows in the current set to see if this set contains the requested address. tag_length = address_length - index_length - offset_length Index The index describes which cache set that the data has been put in. index_length = ceil(log_2(s)), for s cache sets Offset The block offset specifies the desired data within the stored data block within the cache row. offset_length = ceil(log_2(b)), for b bytes per block Tag, index and offset Tag, index and offset Tag and index Only one block is checked for a hit, and only that block can be replaced. Random/LRU/FIFO/Clock Random/LRU/FIFO/Clock Random Candidate blocks are randomly selected. Least recently used (LRU) The block replaced is the one that has been unused for the longest time. First in, first out (FIFO) The block replaced is the oldest block. Clock Search for block with used bit = '0' and reset the bit at the same time. Stop after max. 1 round. Write allocate The block is allocated on a write miss. Write misses do not affect the cache. Instead, the block is modified only in the lower-level memory. No-write allocate Branch Prediction
Contain 1 bit: Jump executed last time (taken) or not (not taken)
Prediction: jump behaves as it did last time
1-bit Predictors Local Predictors 2-bit Predictors Thread Management Mutex Variables Condition Variables OpenMP Parallel Directive #pragma omp parallel Instructs the master thread to Tells the master thread to fork and create a team of threads. Compiler will automatically assign loop iterations to parallel threads. 
clauses : nowait, order, ordered, private, reduction, schedule #pragma omp parallel for Library Functions omp_set_num_threads(num_threads) Affects the number of threads to be used for subsequent parallel regions that do not specify a num_threads clause. omp_get_num_threads() Returns the number of threads in the current team. omp_get_thread_num() Returns the thread number, within the current team, of the calling thread. schedule(schedule_kind, chunk_size) schedule_kind can be static, dynamic, guided, auto or runtime. #pragma omp critical Restricts execution of the associated structured block to a single thread at a time. #pragma omp atomic Ensures a specific storage location is accessed atomically. Data Sharing Clauses default (shared | private | none) shared: All variables shared by default.
private: All variables private by default.
none: Sharing mode for each variable must be explicitly stated. shared (list) Variables in list are shared between threads or explicit tasks executing the construct. private (list) Creates a new variable for each item in list that is private to each thread or explicit task. The private variable is not given an initial value. Reduction Clause reduction (operator : variable_name) At join, local variables are combined and assigned to shared variable. 
operator : +, *, &, |, ^, && or ||
#pragma omp barrier Threads will wait until all threads have reached the barrier. Synchronization Constructs nowait "Overrides any synchronization that would otherwise occur at the end of a construct. " No Wait Clause Order Clause #pragma omp ordered The ordered clause can be used to control the order of some operations within a loop. Work Sharing Constructs #pragma omp sections A non-iterative work sharing construct that contains a set of structured blocks that are to be distributed among and executed by the threads in a team.
 #pragma omp sections
	 {
	 #pragma omp section
				 structured-block-sequence
	 #pragma omp section
				 structured-block-sequence
	 â€¦
	 }
#pragma omp single Some thread will run it. #pragma omp master The master thread will run it. Schedule Clause
